Spring Environment & Profile Handling

Published at: June 2, 2024 | Last modification: June 11, 2024

java Spring

Spring Property

Implementation of the Environment interface collects key-value pairs for configuration purposes from a collection of abstract class PropertySource<T> instances known to that implementation.

Spring’s StandardEnvironment implementation for standalone application is installed with 2 PropertySources:

  1. JVM properties. e.g.
    • java -Djava -Dspring.profiles.active="prof" ...
  2. OS Envvar. e.g
    • export spring.profiles.active=prof1 && java ...

Spring’s StandardServletEnvironment implementation for Web application further includes

  1. A PropertySource that search over ServletConfig parameters & ServletContext parameters
  2. A JndiPropertySource to collect JNDI … TODO

Spring properties can be queried by

1ctx.getEnvironment().containsProperty()
2ctx.getEnvironment().getProperty()

Traditional .property files can be loaded as PropertySource, thus become part of Spring property, by pinning @PropertySource("classpath:/com/myco/app.properties") on a @Configuration class.

Use @Value("${property.name}") to inject value of arbitrary Spring property into a bean’s field or method parameter:

 1@Component
 2public class MyService {
 3    @Value("${myapp.config1}")
 4    String config1;
 5
 6    String config2;
 7
 8    // @Value annotated parameter with default value
 9    public MyService(@Value("${myapp.config2:defaultConfig2value}") String config2) {
10        this.config2 = config2;
11    }
12}

Profile

A Profile is a collection of bean definitions that are loaded by the IOC container only when the profile is active.

Unprofiled beans are always loaded in any profile run.

  1. Add @Profile("profile-names-expr") to

    1. @Configuration class (to include all beans in this class into the profile);
    2. @Bean methods;
    3. @Component and aliked component classes.

    value= of @Profile can either be a string (like "profile-names-expr" above) or be an array (e.g. @Profile({"p1","p2"}) equivalent to "p1 | p2")

  2. Application is run in one or more profiles.

  3. Affected beans are loaded by IOC container only when profile-names-expr is satisfied by current running profiles.

Activate a profile

Multiple profiles can be active in a single run.

Programmatically

A profile can be activated programmatically by calling

1AbstractApplicationContext actx = (AbstractApplicationContext) ctx;
2ConfigurableEnvironment env = actx.getEnvironment();
3env.setActiveProfiles("profile1", "profile2");

where ctx is at least instance of the AbstractApplicationContext interface (i.e. ApplicationContext won’t suffice).

by Spring property

IOC container respect the spring.profiles.active Spring property found from any PropertySource; e.g.

1java -Dspring.profiles.active="prof1,prof2,prof3" ...

The Default Profile

If no active profile is specified in any way, a default profile specified by Spring property spring.profiles.default is considered to be active. If this property is not given, the default profile is named "default".

 1@Configuration
 2public class MyConfiguration {
 3
 4    // without `spring.profiles.active` and `spring.profiles.default`,
 5    // myrepo resolves to `myRepositoryAlter`
 6    @Bean
 7    MyService myService(MyRepository myrepo) {
 8        return new MyServiceImpl(myrepo);
 9    }
10
11    @Bean
12    @Profile("prod")
13    MyRepository myRepository() {
14        return new MyRepositoryImpl();
15    }
16
17    @Bean
18    @Profile("default")
19    MyRepository myRepositoryAlter() {
20        return new MyRepositoryImplAlter();
21    }
22}

Placeholder

Spring supports placeholders in the following places:

  1. vanilla xml bean config:

    1<beans>
2    <import resource="com/bank/service/${customer}-config.xml"/>
3</beans>

  2. TODO

All placeholders will be looked up in Spring properties known to Environment.
